title: Fact #412
text: Wesley Snipes’ footprints are engraved in Calle Della Mariposa in San Juan’s Little Hollywood. It is said that: a) Snipes’ are the only midget feet featured on the two-by-ten foot footpath, and b) when compared to all the other foot molds, Snipes’ feet most closely resemble the footprints left by Diane Keaton.

title: Fact #413
text: Dances with Mice, a wildly popular Puerto Rican version of X-Factor, in which contestants mimicked the frenetic movements of at least six starved rodents trapped in a salad bowl with a live bat, was produced by Wesley Snipes and Robert Duvall.

title: Fact #414
text: The infamous outtake in which a black piano-playing hand appears for a frame in between Dennis Quaid’s in the Great Balls of Fire piano burning scene was originally attributed to a sun-burnt Liberace. Forensic analysis later identified the hand as belonging to Wesley Snipes. Snipes, who long held a grudge against Quaid for taking the title role1 admitted as much to James Lipton during a piano-themed panel discussion on the set of the French Pimp Sessions of Inside the Actors Studio.
notes: <sup>1</sup>For many years Snipes had privately considered himself to be the black Jerry Lee Lewis

title: Fact #415
text: The toe meat underneath Wesley Snipes’ toenails was also black.

title: Fact #416
text: The oft-misunderstood quote Wesley Snipes gave to Vanity Fair editor-in-chief and international pulled pork judge Graydon Carter — “I don’t own a hot tub, I make hot tubs.” — was in fact what Snipes said. While alive, Snipes was an avid designer of hydrotherapeutic hot tubs he never paid taxes on.

title: Fact #417
text: The ill-fated “prison tweet heard around the world” in which Wesley Snipes was thought to have advertised the desire to see the day when the standard unit of trans-American currency was the amputated digits of Mexican postal workers was actually a reiteration of what Snipes purportedly told fellow prison tax evader (and prison computer doubles chess champion) John Heard, who then used the quote in his popular one-man prison stand-up routine Have You Heard?. Snipes, a frequent target of Mexican mail fraud believed (by Snipes) to be the work of Donnie Osmond, originally tweeted: “I hope to live to see the day when the standard unit of currency in Mexico is the amputated digits of Donnie Osmond.”

title: Fact #418
text: In Gary Nelson’s unproduceable Black Hole 2: The Escape (1981-1993), Old B.O.B., the garbage can-sized bio sanitation robot, was to have been played by Wesley Snipes. Snipes turned down the role, citing obvious type-casting considerations. Interestingly, it was Josh Brolin1 who was later cast as B.O.B. Despite the film’s pre-box office demise, Brolin went on to play most of the notable sanitation robots of the 1980s.
notes: <sup>1</sup>Along with father, James, and step-mother, Barbara Streisand, a midget

title: Fact #419
text: Under the name ¡Ay Robusto!, Wesley Snipes was a minor figure in the Cuban Clay Modelers Resistance of the early 1990s. Snipes’ work mainly featured three-inch statuettes of Raoul Castro seated upon a majestic three-speed bidet similar to the one brother Fidel used to navigate the sewer-flooded streets of Brooklyn in the late 1960s.

title: Fact #420
text: In an early 1981 draft of My Struggle dedicated to Wesley Snipes, midget Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard recounted in a lyrical 200,000-word passage a childhood fear of the 1000-meter hurdles. Following ten years of literary rejection — and a two-centimeter yearly shrinkage in height1 — Knausgaard rewrote large portions of the memoir with the aid of Don Rickles. In the 1992 American edition of My Struggle Vol. 1, the dedication to Snipes was missing, replaced, at Rickles’ insistence, with what has been described by film critic Gene Shalit as a “Seussian prologue at whose heart lies [Knausgaard’s] childhood fear of large mouse traps.
notes: <sup>1</sup>Knausgaard suffers from Ousland shrinking midgetism, an extremely rare Norwegian strain of midgetism in which sufferers shrink yearly until they reach a near perfect flatness, at which point they expand again, typically reaching a height of between one and two feet before an agonizing premature death.

title: Fact #421
text: In 1974, a fourteen-year-old Wesley Snipes played Neanderthal snow cone peddler Co-Co-Riki in a Puerto Rican spinoff of the American television series Land of the Lost. Set in a large prehistoric garbage dump in San Juan, Land Where I Ended Up (English translation) ran for eight seasons and was never officially cancelled. In a whimsical turn of events that would redirect Snipes’ career towards mainstream American roles, Lima Bang Studios,1 where Land Where I Ended Up was filmed alongside the Puerto Rican medical clinic drama Heartbeat, burnt to the ground in a chiclet fire.
notes: <sup>1</sup>Bought sight unseen by Nic Cage in 1991 as cheap storage space

title: Fact #422
text: On account of his midgetism, when on shoots Wesley Snipes traveled with a private cameraman<sup>1</sup> for trick shooting. Snipes eventually sought a lawyer to have this arrangement inserted into all his contracts. He was the first actor in Hollywood to pursue height-favorable shooting, now a standard clause in most Hollywood contracts.
notes: <sup>1</sup>Usually Dick Cableman, but on occasion former Mets designated hitter Jose Canseco.

title: Fact #423
text: Wesley Snipes was a polydextrous midget who was capable of writing with eight pencils at one time — one in each hand and foot and an additional two embedded in each nostril.

title: Fact #424
text: Despite his great success in Hollywood, Wesley Snipes always considered himself a celebrity gardener.

title: Fact #425
text: Wesley Snipes’ birth records indicate that during delivery Snipes was officially dead for two hours and eleven minutes.

title: Fact #426
text: Converting his character in Wildcats into a mute wasn’t Wesley Snipes’ idea. Originally, Snipes wanted to play his part in reverse, including his dialogue. Director Michael Richie refused. After Snipes wasted two shooting days in protest, Richie proposed the alternative of letting Snipes play a mute.

title: Fact #427
text: Among copious papers found at the time of his death was a sketch for a Batman character Wesley Snipes had created, possibly for himself. Snipes’ addition to the D.C. universe, “Severance,” was a physically diminutive character who stole and then deposited employee pay checks in a fictional Swiss bank account. In Snipes’ imagining, any employee whose check Severance stole would later become his zombie minion. Severance would also have access to the employee’s health benefits, his hair stylist’s phone number, and to an unlimited supply of oranges. Addditionally, he would convey himself around town in an invisible grain leg five times as big as the Batmobile.

title: Fact #428
text: In Bob Dottie’s original City Slickers (1991) script, a free-wheeling, down-on-his-luck, alcoholic black porter was to follow the three main characters around for most of the film making a nuisance of himself, only to reveal at the very end that he was none other than J.J. Dupree, a fabulously wealthy dentist who not only owned the whole ranch, but owned Jack Palance and Jack Palance’s character, Curly, as well. Problematically, Dupree, who has terminal diabetes, bequeathes his entire estate to one of the city slickers in the final scene, then reneges on the arrangement, finally transferring ownership to Dom Deluise (not even in the film and dead). Wesley Snipes was not offered this role but was said to be the inspiration for it. The working title of Dottie’s script was That Darn Dupree.

title: Fact #429
text: Like most pituitary midgets, Wesley Snipes had a permanently prolapsed anus capable of multi-octave whistling.

title: Fact #430
text: Wesley Snipes was Boris Karloff’s valet for the last ten years of Karloff’s life.

title: Fact #431
text: Before his success as midget Kodak camera salesman PoPo Levine in Good Times, Wesley Snipes played a Moog synthesizer in the Bed Bath & Beyond on 125th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem.

title: Fact #432
text: A recurring motif in Wesley Snipes’ film roles — often ad-libbed and almost always cut — was an infantile fear of falling off the top step of a diving board ladder backwards and landing on his grandmother’s pendulous breasts.

title: Fact #433
text: Among Wesley Snipes’ fondest memories was taking a bath with Herve Villechaize in a jacuzzi-like bowl of chocolate pudding. Tragically, Villechaize died in just such a bowl (bathtub) of pudding (chocolate sauce). At the time of his own death, Snipes was unaware of Villechaize’s passing.

title: Fact #434
text: Kanye West, often confused for a dwarf, was actually, like Wesley Snipes, a pituitary midget.

title: Fact #435
text: Wesley Snipes was tapped as the new host for Family Feud months before Steve Harvey. It was ultimately Snipes’ demands for punitive “loser” laps and a change of name from Family Feud to Feuding that cost him the lucrative announcing job.

title: Fact #436
text: Wesley Snipes christened Sean Combs’ seventh son, Colonel Sanders West Wing Diddy Boy Sean Jr. Combs, at the Tonkawa East Casino on Route 60.

title: Fact #437
text: Only Wesley Snipes’ rib cage and parts of his torso are on display at Madame Tussaud’s in London.

title: Fact #438
text: Wesley Snipes’ mystical Catholic poem Upon the Scaffold of Surmising Him, written to Pope John Paul II upon the death of Sonny Bono, was cited by lawyers at Snipes’ first parole hearing as evidence of Snipes’ willingness to pay his taxes.

title: Fact #439
text: In the director’s cut of After the Sunset, Wesley Snipes was hiding under a dock in a brief scene featuring Salma Hayek. Despite his invisibility, Snipes’ presence somehow disturbed production. In fact, it was subsequently proven by in-house New Line Cinema auditors that intimations of Snipes’ presence in the film cost the studio sixty times Snipes’ value as an actor (had he been hired). The five-second scene was shot a record forty-seven times, costing New Line Cinema $239,000.

title: Fact #440
text: Snipes’ 2002 letter to Harvey Weinstein outlining an all-black remake of <e>Jaws 3-D</e> was one of 1,800 Snipes items bought by Lamont Disney at a Sootheyb’s auction in 2011.

title: Fact #441
text: Long before James Cameron developed his 3-D camera, Wesley Snipes claimed to have developed a “3-WAY” camera. According to child star and celebrity voice coach Shia Labeouf, Snipes’ 3-WAY camera would shoot a single shot three times from three different angles while superimposing a DayGlo image of Snipes’ genitals — only visible to viewers wearing Snipes’ special 3-WAY goggles — over all three. An exhibit of Snipes’ glow-in-the-dark genital art, discovered in April 2016 on the fifth anniversary of Snipes’ death and subsequently purchased by LaBeouf, is on display for a limited time at the Detroit Museum of Fine Art with narration by Ice-T.

title: Fact #442
text: Ghanian myth-buster Theodore Percival Roach II described Wesley Snipes’ Purification Guide for Orthodox Kwanzaa Celebration (Junker International Press, 1998) as a “patchwork of utter fallacy.” Most notable of Roach’s criticisms was Snipes admonition to only take lukewarm showers on the days leading to Kwanzaa. Snipes also exhorted hopeful Kwanzaa celebrants to avoid: anus contact with water, graven images of minibuses, coconuts and the sounds of coconuts, electric static, two-headed toothbrushes (popular in African-American communities at the turn of the century), gas pumps and gas pump cradles that have been recently operated by white hands, and Sylvester Stallone movies. Following Snipes’ death in 2011, Junker International Press re-released the Purification Guide with Roach’s corrections in a limited run of 1,000 copies. The Snipes Estates, on the advice of acting chairman Richard Simmons, purchased 990 of the books. Of the ten that remained in circulation, six have sold on eBay for prices as high as $3.99.

title: Fact #443
text: For five years before he converted to Mormonism, Wesley Snipes ran a nomadic dog grooming service that was eventually shut down when it was discovered that many of the dogs that were returned to their owners were actually charcoal replicas of Herve Villechaize.

title: Fact #444
text: In an unaired episode of the ’80s sitcom Punky Brewster, Punky Brewster has a nightmare in which she is being chased through a library by a gang of angry little people after a squabble over unpaid library fines amassed by her new friend Uncle Broadus. When other sitcom scriptwriters discovered that the gang of angry little people was to be played by Wesley Snipes — thirty-six paid acting jobs — the script was pulled. Witnesses cited Snipes’ previous attempts to maneuver himself into scripts en masse as multiple characters in order to lay claim to union wages.

title: Fact #445
text: On the set of Blade 2, Wesley Snipes’ favored mode of conveyance was a vehicle he called the Duster, a Yuba City Tilt-A-Whirl tea cup he had purchased from actor Nic Cage. According to evidence assembled after Snipes’ death, Snipes had outfitted the two-seat vehicle with a special below-chassis rapid-fire grease gun. It was the grease gun, not the Duster, that became a bone of contention between Snipes and director Guillermo Del Toro’s third personal assistant Mike “Little Guillermo” Alvaredo. Alvaredo claimed, in a now infamous post-production denunciation of Snipes overheard by Patton Oswalt, that Snipes intentionally shot low every time, greasing his genitals. Spokesmen for the Snipes Estate, including its executor, fitness guru Richard Simmons, deny that Snipes ever shot Booster’s genitals with grease when alive.

title: Fact #446
text: According to fellow min-sec tax evader John Heard, Wesley Snipes once did a superb Gilbert Gottfried impersonation during a prison glaze off.<sup>1</sup>
notes: <sup>1</sup>Glaze offs, a mainstay of min-sec life in Pennsylvania prisons, are non-violent monthly competitions in which prison chefs and chefs’ apprentices glaze as many baked donuts as they can in under five minutes. The winner is given a bath by the entire cell block and then tossed from his cell onto a canopy of custard and confectioner’s sugar. The process is repeated twice, according to Heard, at which point the winner is placed before a TV and pretends he is the announcer of whatever program is playing at the time.

title: Fact #447
text: Wesley Snipes is the only known American actor to have punitive damages lodged against him in an Indian court of law for the impersonation of a swami.

title: Fact #448
text: The Waldbaums Giant Wild Tuna Run of 1997 was later cited by Orlando, Florida authorities as grounds for expediting Snipes’ sentencing for multiple counts of tax evasion. It is believed that Snipes, then out of work and struggling with a string of malfunctioning hormone-based growth serums, placed an ad in the New York Post advertising “giant wild tunas [sic]” for ninety-nine cents a fish at a Bronx Waldbaums. The ensuing melee resulted in five hospitalizations and one employee firing.

title: Fact #449
text: The Moldovan city of Felesti erected a life-sized replica of Wesley Snipes in 2006 to protest the second year of Snipes’ incarceration for tax evasion. The memorial, which stood three feet seven inches high and featured a grinning Snipes holding a string of paprika sausages, was dismantled in 2011, the year of Snipes’ death.

title: Fact #450
text: Only weeks before his arrest and subsequent imprisonment for over eighty counts of tax evasion, Wesley Snipes was arrested in the loading dock of a Michaels hobby shop in Herndon, Virginia. Store employees testified later that when Snipes was caught loading hundreds of discount Halloween party favors onto the bed of his Silverado, he assured them that he was doing some pre-shoot scouting for Bad Santa 2 on actor Billy Bob Thorton’s orders.

title: Fact #451
text: Wesley Snipes’ line of half-human, half-plant airport plush toys, Jabbo Friends, sold exclusively at airports in Nigeria, were once thought to be the brainchild of Richard Pryor. In Snipes’ prison autobiography, Snipes, Snipes discredits the rumor, maintaining that while Pryor did once suggest Snipes should sell a line of plush toys, Pryor’s idea was for Snipes to sell “miniature coconut-headed replicas of himself” that would fire very tiny ketchup sachets from their anuses.

title: Fact #452
text: In 2008, a then-destitute Wesley Snipes sold the North American rights to his patented Tootsie Roll-based canine aphrodisiac Love Nubs to Lamont Kardashian for $150,000. According to Kardashian, the product was neither an aphrodisiac nor a dog treat. In seemingly unconnected events, Robert Herjavec of the Shark Tank pledged to buy a thirty-percent share in a “Tootsie-shaped product” also billed as a canine aphrodisiac. Kardashian, at this time living in France, was unable to warn Herjavec, who at the last minute pulled out when Mark Cuban pledged a twenty-nine-percent share and free use of his timeshare in Bermuda.

title: Fact #453
text: An expert at mini-Parkour, Wesley Snipes spent much of his free time in the prison canteen demonstrating miniature feats of Parkour-inspired acrobatics to up-and-coming min-sec Parkour stars.

title: Fact #454
text: Wesley Snipes’ eighth daughter, Jamaica Doodaddle Forest Whitaker Snipes, was christened by prison friend Boris Carradine in Carradine’s signature sleeveless orange jumpsuit.

title: Fact #455
text: Actor Laurence Fishburne blamed Wesley Snipes for his extreme late-life bloating.

title: Fact #456
text: Lionsgate executives had originally tapped Wesley Snipes to play bearded MMA legend Kimbo Slice in their biopic Slice until an internal memo revealed that: a) Snipes was a pituitary midget standing three foot seven, and b) he was dead.

title: Fact #457
text: According to ex-wife Morrisania Burick, Wesley Snipes once pretended to be deaf and blind in order to purchase a discount box of Cohiba cigars at the José Martí Airport duty-free, where, under presidential decree, deaf and blind Cubans were entitled to half-priced cigars. Snipes later challenged the story, claiming that it was his poor grasp of Cuban Spanish and a bad case of pink eye that led the cashier to offer the discount, which he accepted out of politeness. Snipes further claimed that when he learned of his mistake, he donated all his discount cigars to one of Sean Penn’s many Cuban airport charities.

title: Fact #458
text: As Compadre Narwal, Wesley Snipes played opposite Gabriel Byrne’s Captain Quint in a 1996 musical revival of Steven Spielberg’s classic Jaws. According to inside sources, from day one there was friction on the set of the off-Broadway bomb. It all came to a head when Byrne, who had been gravitating towards a lighter-hearted version of Quint with a gift for communicating with porpoises, asked Snipes to throw himself at the shark in one of the musical’s darker scenes where Quint is eaten alive off stage. Byrne’s rationale was that Snipes’ character didn’t even exist in the movie, whereas Quint was a beloved fixture. Snipes refused, claiming that the stage adaptation (penned by Spielberg and Gilbert Gottfried) called for a dramatic flourish in which Narwal stands proudly in the crow’s nest piping out a salute to the dying Quint on the nose harp. In the end, Byrne acquiesced, but out of spite, decided to salute himself on the nose harp. Critics, noting the presence of the second nose harp, were puzzled.

title: Fact #459
text: Wesley Snipes was originally cast for the role of Foman in Aleister Battleman’s Force of Nature. In Battleman’s production notes, Foman was an underwater deity of urban estuaries and canal systems who could, when angered, shoot stoppered sewage at his enemies from a single blowhole atop his head. The part eventually went to Eric Roberts, who prevailed upon Battleman (Time Kills Time, The Cairncross Murders, Boisterous) to relocate the blowhole to a secret throat flap hidden by a multilayered necklace similar to the tiara worn by Osiris Fogg in Battleman’s 1979 remake of Showstoppers. Ironically, on the second day of shooting, Roberts, a crossword champion, lost his memory for forty-two years. By then Snipes had already committed to the voice of Stokey Lokey in the seventh episode of George Harrison’s Thomas the Train, co-directed by Bob Dradle and Sylvester Stallone.

title: Fact #460
text: The owner of the executive hot hub in which John Travolta discovered lost auditions for an all-Puerto Rican remake of Breakin’ 2: Electric Boogaloo was Wesley Snipes. The test reel includes disputed footage of a fourteen-year-old Bradley Cooper attacking Canadian actor Mark Hamill in an unhinged tirade which eventually ended up on a since-deleted TikTok celebrity meltdowns reel believed to have been circulated privately by Connie Sohill, one-time personal trainer to Tito Jackson.

title: Fact #461
text: Wesley Snipes’ code name in William Blister’s 1985 Code Name Moro — “Silent Fist” — was the original name of David Bowie’s second studio album Space Oddity.

title: Fact #462
text: Wesley Snipes was not afraid of heights, but of the way wind felt on the back of his neck at high altitudes.

title: Fact #463
text: Wesley Snipes often said he only bought paint in Portuguese gallons and never in shades of white. And yet after his death in 2011, estate executors clearing out Snipes’ garage discovered a hidden stock of magnolia matte exterior paint specially ordered from Mexico City in ten-ounce Mexican pints.

title: Fact #464
text: Wesley Snipes’ multi-decade feud with Canadian Nickelodeon personality Alanis Morissette had nothing to do with a Green Slime Challenge Snipes wasn’t asked to compete in as You Can’t Do That On Television fixture Carmine, a mute painter who regularly spilled buckets of paint on himself. Rather, it was a comment Morissette is believed to have made upon meeting Snipes for the first time and realizing he was a midget — “Oh, he’s a midget?” — that angered Snipes, who, according to inside sources, heard: “Oh, I don’t work with midgets.”
tags: you can’t do that on television

title: Fact #465
text: A comment Usher made on Tito Jackson’s short-lived PBS talk show Tito in Da House — that Wesley Snipes was the only black man he knew who actually enjoyed visits to the dentist because of the free tutti frutti fluoride treatments — was apparently true.

title: Fact #466
text: Before he became the voice of Minot, the androgynous dad/mom in Master Card’s 2022 “I Didn’t Buy This But I’m Glad I Could Have” ad campaign, Canadian Moody’s dwarf Michael Barbaro worked vigorously with the Snipes Estate to petition the Academy for a posthumous lifetime achievement award for Wesley Snipes, who died in a tax evaders prison revolt in 2011 alongside prison friends “Prince” Ted Cables and Boris Carradine.

title: Fact #467
text: Wesley Snipes was so happy with the anus switchblade Guillermo del Toro designed for him for Blade: Trinity that he had a second and then third installed under each armpit.

title: Fact #468
text: Due to a glitch in Sootheby’s online bidding system, ownership of Wesley Snipes’ Blade: Trinity anus knife is still disputed. According to Sotheby’s, the original bidder “nagasaki chihuahua vomit” (believed to be Mickey Rourke) never made the $60,000 transfer to finalize his bid. According to Rourke’s lawyers, Rourke, who is being sued for the full amount of his bid plus punitive damages, has been publicly sporting his own anus knife since Don Johnson gifted him one on the set of Harley Davis and the Marlboro Man.
tags: harley davison and the marlboro man

title: Fact #469
text: In the early 1990s, Wesley Snipes and producer Earl Davey shot a pilot for a game show they called You Don’t Know What the Price Is, Do You?, in which couples, armed with buckets of KitKats, tried to guess the prices of imaginary products for sale in Latin America. Depending on the caliber of their guesses, contestants would either leave the show with overflowing buckets of candy or shamefully witness the depletion of their buckets. On the verge of defeat, players could opt to reenter compeition either by “leasing” candy from Snipes or selling their feet to the Octo Lady (Laurie Lynn Taylor) and the Tickle Squad.

title: Fact #470
text: Wesley Snipes once sought a patent for an obscure Liberian invention called “Caviar Hose,” which he claimed to have invented with Liberian footbag champion Vormus Kinkaboo.

title: Fact #471
text: Throughout the mid-90s, Snipes promoted his signature version of an obscure Cossack martial art he claimed to have learned from a fellow extra on the set of Red Heat. According to Snipes, his mentor was a Zaporozhian Cossack named Arkady Nugchik, who taught him to incapictate enemy combatants with cement-filled chopsticks. Snipes later claimed to have learned the same skill inside a Siberian men’s prison from a small, heavily tattooed canteen fixer named Maxim Shvets.

title: Fact #472
text: Wesley Snipes’ maternal grandfather, DeMontford “Buckles” Snipes, invented an industrial greasing agent for pinsetter machines in 1939. The original trade name, “Greasy Buckle,” was later changed to “Fubber.” In 1977, Puerto Rican greasing legend Hector Luna bought a controlling share in Fubber, which he marketed with great success to Latin American audiences as a long-lasting shoe heel polish.

title: Fact #473
text: Wesley Snipes learned to play bocce on the set of Pride of Lions with coaching from co-star Jesse Plemmons. After filming, the actors realized they shared more than just a passion for Italian park sports. Plemmons was an amateur remote control tank hobbyist. So was Snipes. Both were midgets and both had at one point in their careers gone to Philip Seymour Hoffman for acting advice without appointments and been rudely shooed out of Hoffman’s apartment by his Xbox golfing partner, Ice-T.

title: Fact #474
text: Snipes’ infamous “twelve o'clock rule,” according to which any leftover catering was his at the stroke of midnight, was a source of confusion and eventually set-wide discord during the making of Timeline Mayo.

title: Fact #475
text: Wesley Snipes said it was Robert De Niro, on the set of The Fan, who advised him to sew an extra back pocket into his ninja costumes. Snipes’ new look would eventually lead to a rift between Snipes and longtime martial arts partner Chris Penn, whose three-pocketed ninja costumes were patent-pending at the time.

title: Fact #476
text: Two months before his arrest for over eighty counts of tax evasion, Beverly Hills police confiscated Wesley Snipes’ motorized hang glider, Belafonte, from the rooftop parking garage of fitness guru Richard Simmons.

title: Fact #477
text: Early into his career, Wesley Snipes appeared in a Canadian truck driver safety PSA. The short film was shot in the far north of Quebec Province, in the wilderness outside Chibougamau. The script described a peppy, freewheeling long-haul trucker named Henri, who stops at a tavern on the edge of town for one last drink on the way to his studio apartment, 374 kilometers away in Chapais. Falling asleep at the wheel, and skidding onto a lake, Henri and his truck sink into an ice hole. Interestingly, director Pierre Patry shot the final scene with one dashboard camera facing Snipes, whose eyes alone, according to the local paper, “accurately foretold Henri’s untimely demise” at the bottom of Lake Simon. Snipes earned $150 for this role.

title: Fact #478
text: According to Gregory Hines historian Herb Hinkley, the scene in the director’s cut of White Nights where Hines’ character, Raymond Germain, breaks the fourth wall and addresses the audience as Forrest Whitaker’s mummy was inspired by a similar scene in Wesley Snipes’ unreleased The Return of Bobo (1988), the only Snipes film Gene Siskel ever awarded four stars.

title: Fact #479
text: Wesley Snipes suffered from a rare, uncatalogued olfactory disorder. When he smelled cinnamon, he would see desert mirages. Reports of an odd, loping gait — a.k.a. “dingo toe” — suggest that when under the spell of an olfactory mirage, Snipes also believed he was a nocturnal quadruped.

title: Fact #480
text: For the past ten years, the editors at Wesley Snipes Facts™ have been meticulously reassembling the varied facts of Mr. Snipes’ very colorful life. As with any project of this scope, sometimes we biographers lose sight of the forest for the trees. In our case, we’ve been laboring onward on the back of a major assumption: that Mr. Snipes was dead. Seven ex-convicts, Boris Carradine among them, and four prisoners currently serving sentences in FCI McKean gave us vivid, if slightly contradictory, reports of Snipes’ death during a prison tax evaders’ revolt. As it turns out, Mr. Snipes did not perish in the revolt. After leaving prison in 2011, he lived for one more year in a Detroit, Michigan loft with a former Bon Jovi drummer, Reginald Bokimps Jr., who murdered Mr. Snipes after a mumblety-peg feud, stabbing him forty-seven times in the prostate.

title: Fact #481
text: In later years, to throw studio executives and tax collectors off his scent, Wesley Snipes spoke pig Latin, in which his driver, household staff, and handlers were all fluent.

title: Fact #482
text: To train for his performance as Morris “Pigs” Ferns in Pit Boss (1996), Wesley Snipes barbecued daily with co-star Billy Crystal’s stunt double, Don Toster, for three months.

title: Fact #483
text: Throughout his career, Wesley Snipes was convinced that the dead actor Herve Villechaize had buried a vast sum of money somewhere on the set of Fantasy Island. In 2006, Snipes enlisted actor Steven Seagal to host a seance over the course of which the two actors confronted Villechaize’s ghost. According to witness Dolph Lundgren, a startled Villechaize insisted that no such money existed. After seventeen hours of questioning, Lundgren said, Villechaize eventually broke down and admitted that beneath his bathtub in Malibu he’d buried a set of alabaster dentures actor Charlton Heston had once slipped into his tuxedo pocket while the two were shooting an episode of Celebrity Squares.

title: Fact #484
text: Matt Damon originally wrote the role of Chuckie Sullivan in Good Will Hunting for Wesley Snipes.

title: Fact #485
text: A CGI recreation of Wesley Snipes starred in portly Russian action star Steven Seagal’s latest film Maximum Vengeance. In the film, Snipes plays Esteban Wimsey, a Puerto Rican Pez merchant hired to assassinate Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko with a poison-filled Pez pellet. Seagal, as Lukashenko’s major-domo/chef, has 432 hours to stop him. According to industry insiders, to save money, Snipes’ CGI avatar was only filmed seated and from behind. The film grossed 500,000 kopeks on its opening day in Minsk. Seagal is expected to release a sequel, Kill Chair, later this year.

title: Fact #486
text: Between 1977 and 1979, Wesley Snipes auditioned a record eleven times to become the fourth member of the Bee Gees.

title: Fact #487
text: In 2022, a decade after his earthly remains were thought to have been launched into space, Wesley Snipes’ partially mummified cadaver was discovered in a cigar box on the desk of guitarist Carlos Santana’s vacation home in Paris’ 14th arrondissement.

title: Fact #488
text: Wesley Snipes’ last known role was Captain Bolus, the fast-talking harem fixer in Kirk Cameron’s twenty-five-minute adaptation of the lost Cecil B. DeMille epic Sodom’s Garden. Snipes was on screen for nineteen minutes of the short film, whispering variously in Aramaic, Pig Latin, and Ancient Nubian. A rotating scroll-activated animation of Snipes as Bolus on the official Sodom’s Garden website was nominated for a posthumous Webby Award in 2020.

title: Fact #489
text: Like his godchild Justin Bieber, Wesley Snipes was an outspoken proponent of fecal powders.

title: Fact #490
text: At the height of his fame, Wesley Snipes owned 110 pairs of Dr. Comfort double depth casual shoes.

title: Fact #491
text: Wesley Snipes was a certified Sealy Posturepedic bed tester, though he claimed to have never accepted a commission. As a reward for his services, Sealy supplied Snipes’ entire prison pod with specially designed orthopedic Murphy beds.

title: Fact #492
text: Wesley Snipes was the original voice of Elmo.

title: Fact #493
text: Wesley Snipes was tapped to play the Ned Beatty character, Bobby Trippe, in Deliverance (1972), but refused to squeal like a pig for author James Dickey in his audition.

title: Fact #494
text: Wesley Snipes’ mint farm, Pinola Glades, sold for a record $1.4 million at a Sotheby’s prison auction in 2008.

title: Fact #495
text: Dudley DeWhicky Snipes, a distant Snipes relation from Boulder, Colorado, owned a string of payday checking stations that doubled as gravestone accessory emporia.

title: Fact #496
text: Wesley Snipes didn’t discover he was a midget until he made a guest appearance on a Brazilian series based on Demolition Man opposite star Egumis Carvalho, himself a midget. The series, Casa de Iguanas de Papel (House of the Paper Iguanas), was banned after five episodes for its depiction of Pope Jean Paul II as a syphilitic vampire’s assistant.

title: Fact #497
text: The ninth item on Wesley Snipes’ bucket list — “to spray Gary Busey’s prized prairie dogs with Glade” — was actually plagiarized from Neil Patrick Harris’s bucket list. According to buseyworld.com moderator R. Avo, Harris had a falling out with Busey after Harris released his three-episode podcast Busey on Busey, where Harris played himself interviewing an unhinged and often delirious Busey (also played by Harris). Originally, Busey claimed Harris had stolen the idea for the show from him. Then, in later episodes of Pet Judge, Busey began to assert that the voices on Harris’s podcast were actually not Harris’s at all but his. When Busey demanded union wages for his performance, Harris responded by threatening to douse Gary’s prairie dogs on The Howard Stern Show. Later, when Harris published his own bucket list, the threat became the 21th and final item. (Harris’s original bucket list, one of the most extensive in Hollywood, was 42 items long.) As for Snipes, in the years since his death, executors have denied the existence of a ninth “plagiarized” bucket list item all together, claiming instead that Snipes had fulfilled all the wishes on his eight-item bucket list before his untimely passing at the hands of Reginald Bokimps Jr.

title: Fact #498
text: In the mid-90s, Wesley Snipes gave several interviews to Black Entertainment Television in which he admitted he was a time traveler from a distant planetary cluster called Megmalt whose overlord was The Goonies co-star and fellow midget Josh Brolin.

title: Fact #499
text: White Men Can’t Jump writer/director Ron Shelton was apparently unaware that Wesley Snipes was a midget when he cast him as Sidney Deane, the trash-talking street basketball hustler.

title: Fact #500
text: Between 1989 and 1994, Wesley Snipes operated a successful furniture slipcover removal service with business partner DePaul Liberace.

title: Fact #501
text: Wesley Snipes is a member of the “Daywalker Klique,” a select group of midgets of color (MOC) who can cook, sing, and defend themselves against muliple attackers at the same time.

title: Fact #502
text: Spike Lee originally tapped Rocky actor Burt Young to play Harlem architect Flipper Purify in Jungle Fever (1991). Wesley Snipes, in fourteen-inch elevator shoes, eventually clinched the role, leading to a few heated script rewriting sessions. Lee had to throw out the rollerblading scene, for example, and put Snipes, a midget, on a modified Big Wheels instead so the height difference between Snipes and Frank Vincent wouldn’t be so obvious. Snipes, who hated colored plastic, eventually relented to the change but insisted the scene be shot in reverse because he couldn’t pedal properly in his heels, infuriating Vincent. If you look very carefully at the crowd of bystanders cheering Flipper Purify on in the final Big Wheels race of the movie, you can see a dissatisfied Burt Young scowling in the background.

title: Fact #503
text: Wesley Snipes was not a martial artist by training, but he once competed in the twelve-and-under Wing Pu Championship in Seoul, Korea, where he disoriented three juvenile opponents by reciting Kwanzaa dietary restrictions.

title: Fact #504
text: Wesley Snipes hated unleaded gas.

title: Fact #505
text: Wesley Snipes was the only midget to have been barred for life from the original Ronald McDonald House in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: Fact #506
text: Wesley Snipes’ second summerhouse, Nevermore, was an homage to Michael Jackson and Earl Piper, the cutman/poet whom Snipes dubbed the “Black Edgar Allan Poe.”

title: Fact #507
text: According to TV host Lou Dobbs and internet guru Neil Patel, both of whom attended Snipes’ prison karate camp, Snipes never studied martial arts but could drive a ski mobile skillfully.

title: Fact #508
text: For the entire shooting of Blade, Wesley Snipes lived inside a 1:8 replica of the Washington D.C. Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which he built himself in the corner of the Disney Studios lot in Burbank, California.

title: Fact #509
text: In the late 1980s, Wesley Snipes sued the World Chess Federation for failing to accept his closing gambit, the Fevquist Lurch, as proof of his Grand Master status.

title: Fact #510
text: In a strange twist of fate, Mike Ouzounian, shoemaker to the stars who made Wesley Snipes’ size-seven Blade platform boots, also served time in a minimum security Pennsylvania correctional facility.

title: Fact #511
text: For a year in between his release from prison and his death at the hands of ex-Bon Jovi drummer Reginald Bokimps Jr., Wesley Snipes made a living performing one-man variety shows on Royal Caribbean Cruises under the name Little Wes and the Squeezebox.

title: Fact #512
text: Blade co-creator Vince Dubbins recalled at a posthumous celebrity roast that he once saw Wesley Snipes shoot himself into the Gulf of Mexico from a small, hand-operated cannon.

title: Fact #513
text: According to co-star Warren de la Rosa, Wesley Snipes purchased a miniature, open-roofed limousine with a self-replenishing charcuterie bar for his work on The Detonator, which he then billed to Sony Studios. The charcuterie limousine was one of many phantom purchases Snipes would later illegally claim as tax write-offs.

title: Fact #514
text: In the early 1990s, Marvel Studio heads wanted Wesley Snipes for the role of T’Challa, King of Wakanda, in the never-released Black Panther: King of Wakanda, not realizing Snipes was a midget. In a lost email, Snipes’ agent at the time, Morris Dakeeny Makondo, bruited the idea of a “Kingdom of Little Wakandans” based on the Ewok Village from Star Wars: Return of the Jedi. The studio response was negative. Eventually, the movie was untabled. By that time, Snipes had already been offered the role of Blade, a midget vampire slayer from the year 2050 who comes back to the year 2000 to cure his genital syphilis.

title: Fact #515
text: In 1986, Star Trek Next Generation showrunner Aaron Sorkin wrote the role of Morbo for Wesley Snipes. An intergalactic gangster who could throw his voice for light years, fooling his opponents into making deadly mistakes, Morbo was expected to be a season-spanning mainstay of the show. However, after an on-set conflict with Wil Wheaton, who claimed Snipes was karate chopping him in the neck off camera, Sorkin rewrote Morbo’s character, calling him Geordi La Forge, a sassy intergalactic ragpicker. The role eventually went to LeVar Burton.

title: Fact #516
text: Before pursuing a career in acting, Wesley Snipes was a human puppet in an Orlando-based traveling puppet troupe called Last Man on Earth.

title: Fact #517
text: In 2009, UFC commentator Joe Rogan approached Wesley Snipes with the idea of a mini prison cage fight series for little convicts called Dust Up, the proceeds of which would go to paying off Snipes’ IRS bills. The first bout, featuring Snipes and Belgian fellow-midget combatant Jean-Claude Van Damme, raised $96,000, but according to Van Damme, neither fighter saw a dime.

title: Fact #518
text: At the height of his fame, Wesley Snipes founded a philosophical school called the Pragmatic Fist, whose main tenet was think before hitting. Snipes personally led many of the early chapter meetings in Los Angeles, but as the philosophy spread and more schools were founded, he delegated most of the day-to-day responsibilities to long-time friend and philosophical sparring partner Richard Simmons. In an interview with James Lipton years later, Snipes admitted that the Philosophical Fist was really a front for an ultra-violent men’s fight club over which he presided as Klung Ban Tou, T’Challa King of Wakanda’s bloodthirsty shadow twin.

title: Fact #519
text: Following the box office success of Time Cop in 1994, Universal Pictures greenlighted an all-black version starring Wesley Snipes as Rudy Burbanks, a wise-cracking accountant from Newark, NJ, who discovers he’s really a fifteenth-century warlock with advanced water dowsing skills. Production on the film, Time Sluice, was halted when Snipes cited contractual obligations to Lions Gate Entertainment, which was producing a Star Trek New Generation spinoff that featured Snipes as intergalactic gangster Morbo, Voice of Many. Unknown to Snipes, the first thirty minutes of Time Sluice was dubbed over and released in Outer Mongolia as The Problem with Rudy, grossing $574,000.

Coming soon. 🔥The Big Book of Wesley Snipes Facts has been over a decade in the making and features over 500 original, hard-to-find facts about midget actor and parkour enthusiast Wesley Peabody Snipes (1953-2012).

title: Fact #520
text: The pint-sized African American in the sombrero on Danny Trejo taco wrappers is Wesley Snipes.

title: Fact #521
text: Wesley Snipes once threw a bag of Cheetos at Dagestani midget UFC champion Little Uri at a charity match in Derbent. Snipes, a midget who knew no martial arts, officially won the fight, but Little Uri later petitioned Dana White to reverse the decision, claiming that Snipes had two left feet (fighting with two left feet is illegal in Dagestan) and had blinded him with Cheeto dust, also illegal in Dagestan.

title: Fact #522
text: Despite a complete lack of martial arts training, Wesley Snipes was known to be a master of jimpenze, an Atlantean variation of Portuguese thumb wrestling in which adept players learned to defeat opponents using both thumbs and, in exceptional situations, their feet.

title: Fact #523
text: In 2020, Lithuanian food writer Biruta Markuza discovered Wesley Snipes’ unreleased biopic of Tobagan yeast eating champion Peno Lentilus in one of Anthony Bourdain’s New York City garages. Bourdain, Markuza claims, had scrawled a short (negative) review on the back of the DVD in women’s pencil eyeliner.

title: Fact #524
text: Wesley Snipes was a lifelong subscriber to Bushcraft Magazine, where he maintained a back-page advertisement soliciting urban python sightings.

title: Fact #525
text: In the 1996 Uwe Boll film Bum Rollers, Wesley Snipes plays a down-at-heel Jamaican dwarf (Sadee) who entertains Wall Street brokers by allowing an unnamed 7-foot sidekick (“the Lug”) — played by Richard Kiel — to hurl him at unsuspecting NYC transit subway workers.

title: Fact #526
text: Before arriving in Hollywood, Wesley Snipes was an amateur garbage collector.  Even as his fame grew, Snipes remained true to waste management, calling it his first love and life’s true calling.

title: Fact #527
text: In his Snipes memoir, Homunculus, Patton Oswalt writes that Wesley Snipes wasn’t only an expert at jimpenze, an obscure variation of Portuguese dirty thumb wrestling, but that he had possibly invented it.

title: Fact #528
text: In an homage to Wesley Snipes, Leave the World Behind director Sam Esmail was said to have originally placed a CGI rendering of the deceased actor as Blade in the window of Danny the Contractor’s (Kevin Bacon) home, instead of Danny’s ten-year-old daughter.

title: Fact #529
text: In an unaired prison interview with Guy Fieri, Wesley Snipes admitted that his karate belts were a fabrication of Woody Harrelson. However, he swore to Fieri and Fieri’s staff that he was a master of cliquot, a medieval Corsican self-defense style that required defenders to catapult themselves off steep mountain paths at attacking sea vessels gripping heavy clay balls calibrated for weight and size. Though the footage never made it into the interview, Snipes demonstrated the technique. According to Fieri, Snipes, a midget, was perfectly in tune with his clay ball, flying at least fifty feet in a smooth, satellite-like motion.

title: Fact #530
text: Chuck Norris’ “Top Ten Friendly Martial Artists” list didn’t include Wesley Snipes. Snipes did cryptically appear on another of Norris’ lists in which Norris kept a record of all the martial artists he had secretly thrown lemons at from his trailer. On the list, Snipes is one of three actors to have been singled out for multiple attacks.

title: Fact #531
text: Wesley Snipes’ 2001 thrift store drama Salvation was the first Hollywood film to raise awareness for the bargain hunter subculture. It was also Snipes’ first collaboration with Woody Harrelson since the two starred in White Men Can’t Jump. In the heavily praised film, Harrelson plays Hunks, the prematurely aged owner of a Salvation Army store where Snipes’ character, Thomas Kimps, shops obsessively for a set of orange glass tea mugs he once saw at a curio shop in Caracas.

title: Fact #532
text: In 2005, Wesley Snipes pitched a cigar abuse comedy to writer and chimpanzee rights activist Aaron Sorkin. The screenplay, based loosely on the Marcello Mastroianni/Ugo Tognazzi comedy La Grande Bouffe, featured Danny Aiello and Danny Glover as two lifelong friends who retire to a cabin in the Poconos to smoke themselves to death upon being diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer. Sorkin rejected the script, but reportedly used it to light a fire on the night he conceived of the pilot of West Wing.

title: Fact #533
text: Wesley Snipes appeared briefly in Midway Games’ Mortal Kombat 3 as Numus, a half-porcupine netherworld combatant who dug holes at light speed and then burrowed inside them, only to pop out from behind — from other holes — and shoot stainless steel quills at his opponents’ genital areas. The character was released in France and parts of West Africa on limited-edition arcade consoles before being discontinued on grounds that were never made clear.

title: Fact #534
text: In 1989, Wesley Snipes and celebrity florist DeFews Geary lost a five-year court battle to trademark the phrase “wipe on wipe off.” Their eponymous modular carwash/pizza parlor in Hollywood’s Little Armenia was subsequently shuttered by court order.

title: Fact #535
text: The idea to make Randall “Tex” Cobb’s character Slow Boy suffer from an unspecified laughing disorder in 1992’s Dome City was Wesley Snipes’.

title: Fact #536
text: In a r/WhoWouldWin subreditt AMA hosted by stuntman Clay Donahue Fontenot, eighty-four percent of reditters said they were unaware that Wesley Snipes was a midget. Twenty-two percent of participants were also unaware that Snipes was dead, and only four percent knew that Snipes was fluent in Pig Latin, but had never studied martial arts.

title: Fact #537
text: While in prison, Wesley Snipes starred alongside fellow convict Romeo Poe in Honolulu Silence, a disaster film that pits Snipes against a minor volcano set to erupt and destroy the chief of police’s rural wedding.

title: Fact #538
text: The music for Ruggiero Bosk’s 1999 adaptation of Wesley Snipes’ one-act play The Leopard Tamer was actually written by Wesley Snipes. It wasn’t until 2006 that the original score for drum brush and vibraslap was adapted for the unreleased O.J. Simpson music video LA Interstate.

title: Fact #539
text: Wesley Snipes couldn’t somersault. For most of his martial arts scenes in the 1990s, Snipes’ shomer Martin Pinkus, a Hasidic Jew from Lakewood, New Jersey, performed the forward rolls and tumbling.

title: Fact #540
text: In 1997, Wesley Snipes and veteran BET showrunner Lief Dardanelles debuted an all-black spinoff of the popular TV series Love Boat called Tug Boat Mack, starring Ossie Davis as Mack, a cantankerous but well-meaning tug boat captain, and Omar Epps as “the Rascal”. Snipes, a midget, made cameo appearances in the first and second seasons as Mack’s dissipated younger brother DeLinear, and then in Season 4, Episode 9 as the mysterious “Monk.”

title: Fact #541
text: Zimbabwean string cheese magnate and Rappelli’s dwarf Elon Musk dedicated the launching of his first cave submarine, the E.M. Intrepidus, to the memory of Bartleby the Scrivener Snipes, Wesley Snipes’ second known child with Vietnamese pit bull trainer Linda Ng.

title: Welcome to WSF
text: Welcome to our new home on the web. Our RSS feed isn’t quite ready yet. But our entire library of over 540 facts about midget parkour enthusiast Wesley Peabody Snipes is ready for reading.
